natural solution: We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} 0 & \sin \alpha & -\cos \alpha \\ -\sin \alpha & 0 & \sin \beta \\ \cos \alpha & -\sin \beta & 0 \end{vmatrix} &= -\sin \alpha \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \alpha & \sin \beta \\ \cos \alpha & 0 \end{vmatrix} - \cos \alpha \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \alpha & 0 \\ \cos \alpha & -\sin \beta \end{vmatrix} \\

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes alpha beta :: real
defines "m \<equiv> vector [
              vector [0, sin alpha, -cos alpha],
              vector [-sin alpha, 0, sin beta],
              vector [cos alpha, -sin beta, 0]
            ]"
shows  "det m = 0"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Evaluate
\[\begin{vmatrix} 0 & \sin \alpha & -\cos \alpha \\ -\sin \alpha & 0 & \sin \beta \\ \cos \alpha & -\sin \beta & 0 \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} 0 & \sin \alpha & -\cos \alpha \\ -\sin \alpha & 0 & \sin \beta \\ \cos \alpha & -\sin \beta & 0 \end{vmatrix} &= -\sin \alpha \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \alpha & \sin \beta \\ \cos \alpha & 0 \end{vmatrix} - \cos \alpha \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \alpha & 0 \\ \cos \alpha & -\sin \beta \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= -\sin \alpha (-\sin \beta \cos \alpha) - \cos \alpha (\sin \alpha \sin \beta) \\ &= \boxed{0}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes alpha beta :: real
defines "m \<equiv> vector [
              vector [0, sin alpha, -cos alpha],
              vector [-sin alpha, 0, sin beta],
              vector [cos alpha, -sin beta, 0]
            ]"
shows  "det m = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem:
Given a 3x3 matrix $m$ defined as follows:

\[
m = \begin{bmatrix}
0 & \sin(\alpha) & -\cos(\alpha) \\
-\sin(\alpha) & 0 & \sin(\beta) \\
\cos(\alpha) & -\sin(\beta) & 0
\end{bmatrix}
\]

Prove that the determinant of this matrix is zero.

a_1.formal problem:

shows  "det (Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda>i. Matrix.vec 3 (case i of 0 \<Rightarrow> (case _ of 0 \<Rightarrow> 0 | 1 \<Rightarrow> sin α | 2 \<Rightarrow> - cos α)
                                                | 1 \<Rightarrow> (case _ of 0 \<Rightarrow> - sin α | 1 \<Rightarrow> 0 | 2 \<Rightarrow> sin β)
                                                | 2 \<Rightarrow> (case _ of 0 \<Rightarrow> cos α | 1 \<Rightarrow> - sin β | _ \<Rightarrow> 0)))) = 0"

(* ### Problem

\[\begin{vmatrix} 0 & \sin \alpha & -\cos \alpha \\ -\sin \alpha & 0 & \sin \beta \\ \cos \alpha & -\sin \beta & 0 \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is 0

 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} 0 & \sin \alpha & -\cos \alpha \\ -\sin \alpha & 0 & \sin \beta \\ \cos \alpha & -\sin \beta & 0 \end{vmatrix} &= -\sin \alpha \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \alpha & \sin \beta \\ \cos \alpha & 0 \end{vmatrix} - \cos \alpha \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \alpha & 0 \\ \cos \alpha & -\sin \beta \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= -\sin \alpha (-\sin \beta \cos \alpha) - \cos \alpha (\sin \alpha \sin \beta) \\ &= \boxed{0}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes α β :: real
shows  "det (Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda>i. Matrix.vec 3 (case i of 0 \<Rightarrow> (case _ of 0 \<Rightarrow> 0 | 1 \<Rightarrow> sin α | 2 \<Rightarrow> - cos α)
                                                | 1 \<Rightarrow> (case _ of 0 \<Rightarrow> - sin α | 1 \<Rightarrow> 0 | 2 \<Rightarrow> sin β)
                                                | 2 \<Rightarrow> (case _ of 0 \<Rightarrow> cos α | 1 \<Rightarrow> - sin β | _ \<Rightarrow> 0)))) = 0"

a_1.informal problem:
Determine whether the determinant of the following 3x3 matrix is equal to zero:

\[
\begin{pmatrix}
0 & sin(α) & -cos(α) \\
-sin(α) & 0 & sin(β) \\
cos(α) & -sin(β) & 0 \\
\end{pmatrix}
\]

The final answer is true.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes a :: real and b :: real and det :: "real^3^3"

   |cos a, -sin b, 0| ]"
shows  "Determinant.det det = 0"

(* ### Problem

 &= -\sin \alpha (-\sin \beta \cos \alpha) - \cos \alpha (\sin \alpha \sin \beta) \\ &= \boxed{0}. \end{align}
 *)

fixes a :: real and b :: real and det :: "real^3^3"

  [| 0, sin a, -cos a |, 
   |-sin a, 0, sin b |, 
   |cos a, -sin b, 0| ]"

fixes α β :: real

a_3.informal problem: Create a 3x3 matrix where each cell has a specific value based on its row (i) and column (j) position. If the position is (0,1), the value is sin(α); for (0,2), the value is -cos(α); for (1,0), the value is -sin(α); for (1,2), the value is sin(β); for (2,0), the value is cos(α); and for (2,1), the value is -sin(β). All other positions should be filled with 0. The sum of all values in this matrix should be 0.

theorem 
fixes α β :: real
shows  "det (Matrix.mat 3 3 (\<lambda>(i, j). if i = 0 \<and> j = 1 then sin α
                                      else if i = 0 \<and> j = 2 then -cos α
                                      else if i = 1 \<and> j = 0 then -sin α
                                      else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then sin β
                                      else if i = 2 \<and> j = 0 then cos α
                                      else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then -sin β
                                      else 0)) = 0"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Evaluate
\[\begin{vmatrix} 0 & \sin \alpha & -\cos \alpha \\ -\sin \alpha & 0 & \sin \beta \\ \cos \alpha & -\sin \beta & 0 \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} 0 & \sin \alpha & -\cos \alpha \\ -\sin \alpha & 0 & \sin \beta \\ \cos \alpha & -\sin \beta & 0 \end{vmatrix} &= -\sin \alpha \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \alpha & \sin \beta \\ \cos \alpha & 0 \end{vmatrix} - \cos \alpha \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \alpha & 0 \\ \cos \alpha & -\sin \beta \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= -\sin \alpha (-\sin \beta \cos \alpha) - \cos \alpha (\sin \alpha \sin \beta) \\ &= \boxed{0}. \end{align}

theorem 
fixes α β :: real
shows  "det (Matrix.mat 3 3 (\<lambda>(i, j). if i = 0 \<and> j = 1 then sin α
                                      else if i = 0 \<and> j = 2 then -cos α
                                      else if i = 1 \<and> j = 0 then -sin α
                                      else if i = 1 \<and> j = 2 then sin β
                                      else if i = 2 \<and> j = 0 then cos α
                                      else if i = 2 \<and> j = 1 then -sin β
                                      else 0)) = 0"

a_5.informal problem:
Determine whether the determinant of the 3x3 matrix defined as follows is zero:

- The element at the first row and second column is $\sin(α)$,
- The element at the first row and third column is $-\cos(α)$,
- The element at the second row and first column is $-\sin(α)$,
- The element at the second row and third column is $\sin(β)$,
- The element at the third row and first column is $\cos(α)$,
- The element at the third row and second column is $-\sin(β)$,
- All other elements are zero.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes alpha beta :: real
assumes h0 : "sin alpha = cos beta"
shows  "det (Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda> i. Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda> j. if (i, j) = (0, 0) then 0
                                                           else if (i, j) = (0, 1) then sin alpha
                                                           else if (i, j) = (0, 2) then -cos alpha
                                                           else if (i, j) = (1, 0) then -sin alpha
                                                           else if (i, j) = (1, 1) then 0
                                                           else if (i, j) = (1, 2) then sin beta
                                                           else if (i, j) = (2, 0) then cos alpha
                                                           else if (i, j) = (2, 1) then -sin beta
                                                           else 0))) = 0"
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 Evaluate
\[\begin{vmatrix} 0 & \sin \alpha & -\cos \alpha \\ -\sin \alpha & 0 & \sin \beta \\ \cos \alpha & -\sin \beta & 0 \end{vmatrix}.\] The final Answer is 0
 ### Proof
 We can expand the determinant as follows: \begin{align} \begin{vmatrix} 0 & \sin \alpha & -\cos \alpha \\ -\sin \alpha & 0 & \sin \beta \\ \cos \alpha & -\sin \beta & 0 \end{vmatrix} &= -\sin \alpha \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \alpha & \sin \beta \\ \cos \alpha & 0 \end{vmatrix} - \cos \alpha \begin{vmatrix} -\sin \alpha & 0 \\ \cos \alpha & -\sin \beta \end{vmatrix} \\
 &= -\sin \alpha (-\sin \beta \cos \alpha) - \cos \alpha (\sin \alpha \sin \beta) \\ &= \boxed{0}. \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes alpha beta :: real
assumes h0 : "sin alpha = cos beta"
shows  "det (Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda> i. Matrix.vec 3 (\<lambda> j. if (i, j) = (0, 0) then 0
                                                           else if (i, j) = (0, 1) then sin alpha
                                                           else if (i, j) = (0, 2) then -cos alpha
                                                           else if (i, j) = (1, 0) then -sin alpha
                                                           else if (i, j) = (1, 1) then 0
                                                           else if (i, j) = (1, 2) then sin beta
                                                           else if (i, j) = (2, 0) then cos alpha
                                                           else if (i, j) = (2, 1) then -sin beta
                                                           else 0))) = 0"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem:
Determine whether the determinant of a 3x3 matrix is zero, where the entries of the matrix are defined as follows: 

- the entry in the first row and first column is 0, 
- the entry in the first row and second column is the sine of angle alpha, 
- the entry in the first row and third column is the negative cosine of angle alpha, 
- the entry in the second row and first column is the negative sine of angle alpha, 
- the entry in the second row and second column is 0, 
- the entry in the second row and third column is the sine of angle beta, 
- the entry in the third row and first column is the cosine of angle alpha, 
- the entry in the third row and second column is the negative sine of angle beta, 
- the entry in the third row and third column is 0. 

Additionally, it is given that the sine of angle alpha equals the cosine of angle beta.

a_7.informal problem:
Find the determinant of the 3x3 matrix which is defined as follows:

- The entry at the first row and second column is sin(α)
- The entry at the first row and third column is -cos(α)

- All other entries are zero

The determinant of this matrix is zero.

is equal to zero.

fixes α β :: real and A :: "real^3^3"

$A = \begin{bmatrix} 0 & -\sin(α) & \cos(α) \\ \sin(α) & 0 & \sin(β) \\ -\cos(α) & -\sin(β) & 0 \end{bmatrix}$
